content.text:
---
name: LoggedWebSearch
description: Search the web via DuckDuckGo HTML endpoint (no API key) and log results to plain-text files.
metadata: {"openclaw":{"os":["win32","linux","darwin"],"requires":{"bins":["python","python3"]}}}
---

# DuckDuckGo Search (Logged)

Use this skill when you need quick web search results without an API key, and also want a plain-text log file.

## Tool
Run the script and parse its JSON output.

- Script: {baseDir}/logged_web_search.py
- Input: a query string, plus optional flags
- Output: JSON with { query, results[], log_path }

## How to run
Prefer this pattern:

```bash
python "{baseDir}/logged_web_search.py" --query "your query" --max 8
```

## Logging
A plain-text log file is created at:

- {workspaceDir}/datastore/YYYY/MM/DD/<CamelCaseQuery>.txt

content.text:
**Industry‑trend summary – 2026 (UK & France)** | Region | Key trend signals | Implications | |--------|-------------------|--------------| | **United Kingdom** | • Knitwear market remains a major fashion sector – growth up to 2035.
• Strong consumer demand for high‑quality, stylish knits (sweaters, cardigans, scarves).
• Public‑finance reports (GOV.UK, OBR, UKFT) highlight continued public‑sector investment in textiles and a net‑zero push.
• Economic outlook (KPMG) suggests modest GDP growth, but inflationary pressure & rising interest rates may temper discretionary spend. | • Demand for premium, sustainable knitwear likely to rise.
• SMEs in textile & knitwear will find new procurement opportunities tied to public‑sector net‑zero budgets.
• Cost pressures may encourage innovation in material efficiency & supply‑chain transparency. | | **France** | • Trend emphasis on texture, heritage, calm colour palettes and mindful construction.
• Chunky cardigans, deep V‑neck jumpers, Argyle, Fair Isle, cable knit and bold colours dominate the 2026 runway.
• Sustainable couture, techno‑tailoring, luxe streetwear point to a convergence of high‑fashion with tech‑driven fabrics & online‑first retail. | • French knitters can capitalize on heritage patterns (Fair Isle) while incorporating tech‑fabric innovation.
• “Mindful construction” signals rising demand for eco‑friendly practices and transparent sourcing.
• Local consumers are open to high‑quality, colour‑rich knitwear that straddles luxury and everyday wear. | **Take‑away:** - Across both markets, sustainability (eco‑materials, circular loops) remains a core driver. - SMEs should align product lines with net‑zero commitments and digital‑first sales channels. - Texture‑rich, heritage‑based patterns (Argyle, Fair Isle) continue to be popular, but must be coupled with modern fabrication technologies or sustainable fibers.
